Problem:
Analyze a continuous-time system represented by the integral equation \\( y(t) = \int_0^t e^{(t-s)A} u(s) ds \\), where \\( A \\) is a matrix and \\( u(s) \\) a varying vector function of time. Study the effect of applying a temporal shift transformation defined by the function \\( f(u) = e^{B\tau}u(t-\tau) \\), with \\( \tau \\) a time shift constant and \\( B \\) another matrix.

If the function \\( f(u) \\) is applied to the input function \\( u \) at time \\( t = 0 \\) and then the system evolves under the integral equation without further intervention, will \\( y(t) \\) at time \\( T \\) be affected by the transformation \\( B \\)?
Explanation: By applying the transformation \\( f(u) = e^{B\tau}u(t-\tau) \\), the input function is altered early in the system trajectory, impacting how \\( y(t) \\) evolves according to the integral equation. The shift and matrix \\( B \\) change the integration dynamics and therefore the state output at any time T, dependent on both \\( A \\) and \\( B \\).
